author: nick.odio
title: MultiSwap (X-Chain Swaps by Ferrum)
description: Secure multi-chain aggregators, interoperability protocols, & cross-chain swapping platforms connecting L1 solutions to both eUTXO and EVM compatible networks are non-existent in todays landscape.

f6_assessments.q0:
To understand where this proposal is coming from, you need to understand the general issues that face interoperability between tokens on different chains.  When the links between chains are created (usually as bridges) there are a limited number of ways for the value to cross the bridge.  Most of these ways involve parking or burning the token on its home-chain, and using some kind of validator to prove that the value in the tokens has been locked down or out, thus allowing that value to be represented on the new chain.  The description of a "bridge" leads many to think that the token has managed to "cross" over to the new ecosystem, but in almost every case, the tokens are actually held in a locked pool, with much less security than is present on the L1 protocol, while a doppleganger (and all too often this faux version of the token is stripped of valuable utility) roams around on the new chain.

Obviously, this lower security and pooling creates attractive targets for hacks, and of any recent hacks you can think of, chances are they were of this bridge vulnerability variety.

Multiswap reimagines this vulnerability by eliminating the concept of the bridge, and instead tries to build liquidity protocols so that instead of transforming the token itself though a trust layer, the token is swapped for value on the other side of the divide.  The impact on the interoperability long game cannot be understated here, and Ferrum is as far ahead as anyone on this tightly competitive arc into the multi-chain future.

Some of these liquidity protocols are of the "white label" variety (the token project itself provides excess value in the new ecosystem) while others lean into liquidity protocols of the dexes themselves.  When you start adding in the utility of the Ferrum native assets FRM and FRMx to generate investment and yield opportunity, as well as "mini-impact" from things like the tax-accounting viability of being able to keep a token's value intact through the swap, it is clear that this is a stable plan with wide ranging synergy with Cardano and its users.  I believe this proposal merits 5 stars for its alignment to both the cross-chain requirements of the challenge setting as well as the wider interoperability and scaling principles of Cardano.
f6_assessments.q1:
While the team is helpfully listed and linked in the proposal, following through any of their project links takes us into the depths they have already plumbed with this project, the multitude of partnerships and clients they have worked with, and I find this to be an extremely valid form of referential trust.  By checking out some interviews they gave I found their broad knowledge of the space between chains, and their specific knowledge of discrete chain protocols to be very reassuring.  They recognize the problems in the space, and also, importantly, the recognize that there are tradeoffs for any particular approach, including their swapping protocols.

Their timeline and milestones are extremely granular, listing out each milestone by number of days.  There were a couple of issues however.  One was an issue of clarity:  the team refers to several deliverables as being submitted to Catalyst for bug testing, signing off on shell apps and approving milestones.  This is likely a bit of confusion from applying this model, which has already been applied to many other projects, to the more decentralized Cardano.  In practice, none of these suggestions are issues, since there is a community to provide feedback and test, a robust technical community to analyze repos and of course, IOG with oversight of Coordinator for approving funding tranches.  If any issues arise, it will be due to funding tranches not lining up with expenses and misunderstandings that can arise from this lack of familiarity with Catalyst. It is highly recommended that the proposing team reach out to funded proposers to get a feel for how the funding is distributed.

Further, there is an issue around the lack of a budget breakdown.  The team clearly has an understanding of the resources required to integrate a new chain, but without providing any details, there is no way to assess whether the number they have presented is realistic, or whether it might be over- or undershooting their needs.  For what it is worth, for the scope of the work they are describing, this feels a bit under-budgeted, but it would be nice to have better numbers to reach that conclusion more firmly.  Along similar lines, and just as advice to the proposer, it would be handy to see the timeline summarized to include the total length of funding required for the project (as this number is used to divide the funding up into monthly tranches).

Despite a strong team, a robust product that is available and working on other chains, a nuanced iterative approach and a deep knowledge of the space, I'm afraid I have to deduct a star for the lack of a clear budget and the uncertainty it creates in an otherwise solid proposal.  4 stars for Feasibility.
f6_assessments.q2:
This project is written up here as primarily a software delivery, and as such they have included the dependable Jira tools and agile methodology.  There is a note about being familiar with sprint burndowns for reporting progress as % complete which is always an excellent add.

It is worth noting that they have a large section included under feasibility which actually lends a whole lot of auditability trust to the project.  The section covers what looks like a grassroots marketing approach, but which will actually function as a great transparency/availability layer for community feedback and interaction.  On top of this they have included a vow(!) to present monthly resource reports on anything required, and in particular transparent expense reports.

Because the audit points they have included indicate that they are familiar with the tools they need to use, as well as their ability to address any shortcomings related to their presentation of the budget, I believe they have presented a proposal that can be effectively audited and monitored by the community, so I give a full 5 stars.

f6_assessments.q0: The proposal aims to build a multichain swap with can being in following advantages. 1. 2-way bridge LP system which is more secure than mint/burn algorithms. 2. At the same time the protocol offers a reflection (RFI), dividend, or burn mechanism. 3. The proposed protocol will never have control over the token contract of any asset using the protocol. 4. This protocol will use uses the APIs from DEXs and tap into DEX liquidity to support the volume being transacted across the protocol. The protocol removes the wrapper function involved in mint/burn multichain protocols thereby the UX is greatly improved. On analysis of the advantages, number 3 alone has substantial merit to rate this proposal as one of the far-reaching proposals in Fund 9. There is a need for such a fundamental contribution and in this respect, the proposal is outstanding since it offers a unique way to move assets between chains at the same time the smart contract will be able to be used to exploit the assets movement since it is not controlling the assets in both the chains. Therefore the project is very much in alignment with the challenge.

f6_assessments.q0: I think this proposal is trying to provide Cardano with its own Ethereum’s 1inch but with added benefits of multi-chain interoperability via novel two-way LP bridging system, instead of just aggregating liquidities domestically inside the native blockchain. This proposal will help us to gain access to the resources of EVM chains out there. Given the Basho era we are in now, I think the majority of the community is focusing much of their attention in scaling solutions and put interoperability solutions kind of in the sideline. Therefore, I think this proposal could be a good investment for Cardano community to prepare ourselves in addressing and delivering more accomplishment in interoperability area. The fact that this proposal is in the right challenge of Cross-Chain Collaboration adds further conviction to me.
f6_assessments.q1: The company itself looks very solid and respectable. Track records and achievements can be easily verified via LinkedIn URLs provide for each team member. The team also looks sizeable with good sets of business and technical functions. Milestones, deliverables, and budgets are very well-written and well-detailed. From my basic calculation, the project is planned to be finished in 36 working weeks (180 working days) and assuming 40-hour work week I got hourly rate of this proposal service and delivery of around USD 140. I think this is a fairly reasonable rate since there will be business/project manager, marketing specialist, and most importantly multiple developers and security auditors working to implement and deliver this holistic solution. Technical rationale is detailed in place and satisfactory. The team also explained the security risk as common hindrance in inter-blockchain bridging solution. They addressed it through updating Node Signing Architecture and related Infrastructure to enable decentralized Node signing which resulting in extra security and reliability layers.
f6_assessments.q2: Most of the project work will be executed in SCRUM tactics with two-week sprints which is standard in the software development industry. The Catalyst community as the gatekeeper of this project can use a provided open-sourced Jira board to monitor the progress further. The team will also commit monthly Progress Updates to Catalyst and IOG, including the deliverables being worked on and financial expenditure and utilization analysis. I love the ambition from the proposer team to make the delivered product talk of the (Cardano) town on all media. Furthermore, they will also provide marketing and communication to Cardano community members and wider crypto audience outside Cardano through highly informative, quality articles, public relations and influencer campaigns, youtube podcasts & Series, social media & lead generation, e-mail blasts, AMA sessions, website promo, and in-house sales and product representatives. f6_assessments.q0:
This proposal is about creating 'Multiswap,' a smart routing multi-chain aggregator and cross-chain swapping platform. It aims to provide Cardano multi-chain aggregator and swaps between Cardano and other chains such as Ethereum, BSC, Polygon, Avalanche, Harmony, etc. Therefore, it is aligned with the Challenge statement as it is trying to provide Cross Chain solutions.

It will add much value to the Ecosystem as it will be the first solution on Cardano to provide interoperability with more than one chain. We already have Milkomeda, which provides interoperability with Ethereum. If successful, this will increase on-chain activity from the users on other chains.

The proposer mentioned the risk would be security breaches which is the case for any protocol operating on the blockchain. He has measures planned to address such risk, along with the fact the protocol will undergo Smart Contracts Audit before launch.
f6_assessments.q1:
The proposer provided brief details of the team along with their LinkedIn profiles. As it seems from the details in the proposal and on LinkedIn, they are skilled and qualified to execute the proposal. But the details of their roles in the proposal are not provided.

The detailed plan of the proposal is divided into five milestones. Each milestone is assigned with the tasks to be completed in those respective milestones. It is also provided with the duration required to complete those tasks, which is Milestone 1 -> three weeks (21 days), Milestone 2 -> 67 days, Milestone 3 -> 45 days, Milestone 4 -> 30 days, and Milestone 5 -> 15 days. Thus, the required duration adds up to 178 days, less than six months. Therefore, it is reasonable considering the volume of tasks to be completed.

The requested budget is $200,000, more than 22% of the Total Challenge amount. It is a big amount but can be justified based on the proposal as it attempts to provide a cross-chain solution between Cardano and more than seven other chains.

But the proposer did not provide the breakdown of this budget. The proposer should have broken it down into identifiable tasks of the proposal. It helps the readers in evaluating the proposal and also in tracking/auditing the progress of the proposal.
f6_assessments.q2:
As stated by the proposer, they will post the proposal developmental updates on the Jira board to track the progress of each task. Also, they will submit progress reports and financial reports to Catalyst every month. All these can be utilized to track/audit the proposal's progress.

The proposer laid out the milestones with the duration required. As stated above, the proposer divided the proposal into five milestones, all of which will be completed within 178 days. Each milestone is assigned with a specific timeframe; this certainly helps the tracking.

As mentioned above, the proposer asked for $200,000 but did not provide the breakup of this amount. Hence it is unclear how he will spend the amount on which tasks. It also hampers tracking/auditing. 
As stated by the proposer, success will be considered when the product is deployed, and the protocol will substantially increase the transaction volume contributed by the protocol.

f6_assessments.q0:
Ferrum is an online DeFi / staking solution that has already applied for funding in Fund 8, with four proposals, fairly similar in scope / presentation, and all of them having received mixed reviews from the community. None of them were funded, and the Ferrum team is back now in Fund 9 with a single proposal, a very positive sign that shows they have at least learned this lesson - that their strategy of splitting a project into multiple proposals proved to be confusing for the community. Let’s see how else they managed to improve their value proposition.  

As a refresher from F8 information we already know, Ferrum has been present in the crypto space since 2018, with services initially offering services for ETH, MATIC, BSC and AVAX. Now, at least judging by their website, their services are much more elaborate and fairly complex (staking lotteries, NFT products, web3 games, etcetera) and very wide in scope. 

With this proposal they are asking for funding to provide a …multiswap integration, but since it’s not actually clear so I will quote them, maybe you understand better: “MultiSwap reimagines architectural & OpSec best practices, providing a complete solution on the market while encouraging TVL across Cardano native DeFi protocols”. So there you have it! 

Just as it was the case with their Fund 8 proposals, I am not convinced that there is a good fit with the challenge. Back then, Ferrum was unsure that there was a potential for their service to be integrated with Cardano. A few months have passed, and by reading the proposal we are not actually understanding if there is a good fit now. Have Ferrum taken a closer look at their services and development plans and did they come up with a viable avenue for integration? We are not being told, and the proposal does not mention this aspect. The proposal sadly maintains the same fuzzy logic and argumentation style that was confusing for the community in Fund 8 even now - since it’s not easy at all to understand their explanations. 

Considering all of the above I can only offer two stars - since the Ferrum team does not bring before us a solution that is easy to understand and they bring no arguments why it will be beneficial for the Cardano community.
f6_assessments.q1:
The team behind Ferrum seems very strong, and they have made an excellent effort into presenting themselves. Naiem is the founder, with previous experience working for Microsoft and Amazon. Ian, the COO, is a lawyer by formation and has joined Ferrum in 2018. These are just two examples, but more team members are presented within the proposal, and many more are available on their website - most of them with Linkedin profiles available, so definitely the team presentation is a strong point of the proposal. 


From a budgetary point of view, this proposal is very very similar to the ones they proposed in Fund 8. So my words are pretty much the same. The budget has used absolutely no figures whatsoever. The entire budget section is simply an argument as to why granting the funds is necessary in order for Ferrum “to be able to justify prioritizing this integration [...]  cognizant of their backlog”. Rephrasing the argument, for me it sounds more like “we are not entirely sure that there is a business case to be made here, but if you fund us we shall make an effort”. These are the exact words that again, confused the Catalyst assessors in the previous round and it is very sad to see that the Ferrum team had not learned from the feedback provided.   

Timewise, they offer 5 milestones. During the first a scoping exercise would be completed (20 day).  The second would see a bridge shell app being built and deployed internally (75 days). The third would involve testing by Catalyst and audit submission (30 days). For this phase it is rather unclear who from Catalyst would test it (will it be in beta mode available for anyone?) and what kind of audit submission we are talking about. Is it a third party audit? Who is the auditor, do they have a budget set aside? The fours milestone would be a multi-chain aggregator deployment and testing (35 days). The last phase would take into account the feedback provided and would see the live launch (20 days). So a rather concrete plan with clear milestones - definitely a strong point of the proposal. 

No matter how strong the team presentation is, no matter how well defined the milestones are, the fact that the budget contains NO figures whatsoever does not allow me to offer more than two stars in this category. I consider it a very poor practice to do this and to my mind this fact renders the project rather unfeasible to implement correctly, if funded.
f6_assessments.q2:
Their auditability section is very very close to the ones they had in Fund 8, hence my words are almost the same as well. The team uses SCRUM and runs 2 week sprints. They promise an open sourced Jira board to track the progress of each task and they also promise to to provide Progress reports and financial reports every month. 

Measuring the project’s success is rather confusing when judging by what the proposers offer us. They use a negative sentence so I am quoting them by turning it into an affirmative one: “The project will be considered a success when the product is deployed to production and we are seeing substantial transaction volumes and assets listed on the aggregator”. Sadly they are not actually offering any anchors to base our expectations: what constitutes a substantial volume of transactions? Which exactly are the assets we are talking about? Although, interestingly enough, a few of the assessors this time around explained that they thought this proposal should’ve been broken into multiple proposals. Either way, we really hope this is the best option here.  Furthermore, the last proposals totaled 300k between the 3 proposals as opposed to 200k for this one. After talking with the devs and the rest of the team, we agreed that we could build the product for 200k in an attempt to go for the entirety of the funding at once since our previous strategy of separating the proposal into phases failed. We figured that approaching this more leanly than we had originally intended and getting it done was more important than risking missing the opportunity to help grow the Cardano ecosystem. 

We’re a bit unclear on what you mean when you say that Ferrum was “unsure that there was a potential for their service to be integrated with Cardano” and that “we are not actually understanding if there is a good fit now.” We are quite certain that MultiSwap is an incredible fit for the Cardano ecosystem. There are very few highly connected interoperability protocols in the Cardano ecosystem. MultiSwap IS highly connected; not only to a dozen or so EVM networks but also some non EVMs as well. Also, it will not only function as a bridge but it will function as a cross-chain swapping protocol as well. Meaning users can Swap ‘Asset A’ on the origin network for ‘Asset B’ on Cardano. Furthermore, with the frequency in which ‘bridges’ are exploited, we believe that a securely architected interoperability protocol is absolutely crucial for the Cardano ecosystem. Other reasons as to why we believe this product will be beneficial for the Cardano community include encouraging TVL and volume on DEXs such as Wingriders, MinSwap, SundaeSwap and MuesliSwap, making Cardano native assets more composable, and serving as a conduit to facilitate porting liquidity to Cardano. It also removes a barrier of entry for multi-chain projects who have an active investor and user base on other existing and established networks.


When you say “Have Ferrum taken a closer look at their services and development plans and did they come up with a viable avenue for integration?” Yes! We absolutely did. This was one of the main reasons why we opted against submitting a proposal for our Staking as a Service solutions like we did for F8. We wanted a renewed and more narrow focus this time around and thought the best approach would be to start with the biggest hurdle; interoperability. Think of MultiSwap as Phase 1 of the relationship between Ferrum and the Cardano community. Phase 1 is integrating MultiSwap and our Bridge protocols along with the underlying node infrastructure with Cardano. Ultimately though, Ferrum’s success is intended to be aligned with the success of Cardano. We want to build here because Cardano is projected to shape the future of crypto and blockchain at large over the next few years. But after receiving the feedback from F8 we decided that in order to ensure the success of this relationship, we will first integrate MultiSwap, THEN integrate our staking solutions so we can offer them  to projects on Cardano in order to incentivize TVL to move to Cardano and give new projects a way to provide instant utility for their community as they build their core products out here.
